results.title: Japan: the collective giant
results.creator_credit: Gerald Renaud, Irwin Rosten, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Films Incorporated
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Japan: imperial power to industrial giant”.
Deals with management-employee relationships of Japanese corporations and the fact that this country has a highly productive labor force which has become a threat to other countries. Points out that industrial prosperity can bring mixed blessings such as transport problems and pollution.

results.title: A Nation transformed 1945-1965
results.creator_credit: Gerald Renaud, Irwin Rosten, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Films Incorporated
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Japan: imperial power to industrial giant”.
From the ashes of total defeat Japan rose in 21 years to an unparalleled economic and social level. The film portrays this remarkable recovery, noting the influences of MacArthur, the fierce national pride of the Japanese, and the new ideas of democracy. Suitable for upper primary and secondary levels.

results.title: Japan: a century of imperialism
results.creator_credit: Gerald Renaud, Irwin Rosten, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Films Incorporated
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Japan: imperial power to industrial giant”.
Using documentary footage, this film traces the rise and fall of Japanese imperialism between the years 1850-1945. It gives insights into Japan’s internal political struggles, its militaristic philosophy, and the role of the United States in providing Japan with the tools of war.

results.title: A Nomad boy
results.creator_credit: Denis Hargrave, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and UNICEF
results.brief_description: Portrays Somalia, an African country near the Red Sea, with emphasis on its nomadic camel herders. Features Ismael, a 12-year-old boy, who spends his life searching for pastures for his flocks. Suitable for upper primary and lower seconday levels.

results.title: A Musician in the family
results.creator_credit: Gudrun Parker, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The young son of a prairie farmer, against considerable opposition, achieves his ambition—a musical education. Andrew’s father fears that a musician in the family may affect the future of the farm, and tries to discourage the boy’s attachment to his trombone. On Andrew’s side are his mother, his teacher and a neighbour, while the farm animals patiently serve as his rehearsal audience. Perseverance wins him a place among the contestants in the annual provincial music festival, and the encouraging words of the adjudicator help sway his father to acceptance of the boy’s music.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Gudrun Parker, Guy Glover and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: A Mongolian tale
results.creator_credit: Xie Fei, Ma Fung Kwok, Wellington Fung and China Film Co
results.brief_description: This film attractively depicts the harsh life of the Mongolian Steppes, it is a deeply moving film. An old woman lives a lonely traditional life on the beautiful Mongolian Steppes. She and her orphaned granddaughter eke out a living as shepherds. When a fathers asks to leave his little boy with them to be brought up, the old lady acepts gracefully. The children grow up a brither and sister, learning to survive the blistering summers and freezing winters. They cant afford a horse, but as fate would have it, a lost foal wanders into their compound one cold night and becomes the boys proudest possession. The children grow up and become engaged, the young man leaves for the city and an education. Upon his return, his sweetheart has become pregnant to the local bully In Chinese with English subtitles.

results.title: A Matter of survival
results.creator_credit: Bernard Devlin, Bill Brind, Canada Department of Labour and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: Much has been said about the predicament of the blue-collar worker in the automated world of industry. This film is about a similar threat to the white-collar worker in the business world. It portrays a situation in a company where computer methods are about to be introduced to take over much of the paperwork, consequently “making surplus” a number of responsible, long-time employees. The film poses the problem from the points of view of both management and of the employees concerned. Awards: New York; Antwerp; Knokke
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bernard Devlin, Bill Brind, Canada Department of Labour and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: A Matter of choice
results.creator_credit: Allan Goldstein, Jason Paikowsky, National Film Board of Canada and Tetra Media Productions
results.brief_description: Nuclear power is the subject of this film that opens with a tour of the Bruce Nuclear Power Plant located on Lake Huron near Port Elgin. Questions regarding safety, cost and decision-making powers are raised by various people in the area. In view of Ontario Hydro’s plans to complete by 1983 the construction of several plants at a projected cost of $22 million, this film examines a timely and controversial issue. Interviewer: Howard Hutton. Narrator: Christine Johnston.

results.title: A Matter of choice
results.creator_credit: Keith Hounslow, Valentine Stewart and Crawford Productions
results.brief_description: The Colleges of Advanced Education both in the metropolitan area and the country offer alternative career training to the Universities as well as their role in technological training with which the public is already familiar. The colleges train students for careers in business and advertising, paramedical and other fields. From a treatment by Jim Harris.
